Home » News » Workers shut C-River LG Ministry, HoS office over 8 months unpaid salaries Workers shut C-River LG Ministry, HoS office over 8 months unpaid salaries On 3:56 am In News by Okogba Comments 
By Ike Uchechukwu 
C alabar— AGGRIEVED council workers and primary school teachers, led by Nigeria Labour Congress, NLC, and Trade Union Congress of Nigeria, TUC, leaders, have shut Cross River State Ministry of Local Government Affairs and the Office of the state’s Head of Service over alleged eight months unpaid salaries. 
Vanguard learned that the aggrieved workers commenced their action on Tuesday from the Office of the Head of Service and continued to the Ministry of Local Government Affairs yesterday, threatening to extend the protest to other ministries should the authorities fail to address their grievances. 
It was gathered that organized labour in the state plans to declare a total industrial action should the ongoing action fail to yield the desired result. 
Speaking to Vanguard yesterday, state NLC Chairman, John Ushie, said the picketing became necessary because labour had exhausted all other avenues including dialogue and singing of MoUs in October last year. 
He said: “As I speak to you, there are local government workers and primary school teachers who have not received salaries since June 2016.We discovered that a lot of our colleagues are dying, some are bedridden and many others can no longer take care of their responsibilities as parents because they no longer receive salaries. If nothing is done after this exercise we shall review our stand and go on total strike because an injury to one is an injury to all. It is obvious that the consultant they brought to do the personnel audit did not do a good job.” 
Ushie insisted the labour was not against personnel audit, but wanted the job of the consultant to end at screening and not payment of salaries. 
The TUC Chairman, Clarkson Out, corroborated Ushie’s claim. 
Efforts to reach the Commissioners for Local Government Affairs and Finance, John Ulafo, and Mr. Asuquo Ekpeyong Jnr respectively were unsuccessful as they were not answering their calls.
